reviewText: If you have seen "Eye of the Needle" (1981), then you will probably like this movie as they are both good adaptations of Ken Follett Novels. However this one was a mini series on TV so there was not as much thought put in to it as if it were a made for theater movie. However the film was made in Tunisia.David Soul is caste as Alex Wolff, which matches the book description pretty well. Robert Culp is comfortable as General Rommel.You will have to look real hard at the credits to see that Season Hubley plays Elene Fontana.My favorite surprise was seeing Richard Gibson playing a British officer named Captain Newman and speaking with a British accent. As I remember him as Otto Flick (Flick the Gestapo) in "'Allo 'Allo" (1984) [TV-Series: 1984-1992]I can see the "R" rating, as there are plenty of risqué shots of men and women, and women and men, and women and women.There are enough plot twists to keep your attention.
summary: A made for TV movie that is close to the book
Title: N/A

reviewText: How did we manage to lose the brilliant David Soul to Great Britain - where he pursued an excellent career? I guess that his past in Starsky and Hutch played against him. He is here as good as was Brando in a similar role -The Young LionsHe plays the cruel deviant German, so strong that it is a bit at the expense of the other characters. It was an excellent series.I have not lost all hope to see it come in the US-format, it was one of my favorite VHS.

reviewText: I've been waiting and waiting.  I really want to get the DVD, 'cause I've already replaced too many tapes that have been worn out or eaten by by VHS machine.
summary: So where is the DVD release?

reviewText: They did a great job with this movie, it's not easy moving a story from book to screen. David Soul did a wonderful acting job as Alex Wolff. His mix of bad guy and a romantic were very well done and realistic. Cliff Robertson was also great, as well as the locations for shooting. Some spy type movies tend to get boring for me, but the casting in this, as well as a great story made it anything but boring. It's a long film, 3 hours, but because the film is so good, time flies by very quickly. It's definetly a movie you will watch more than once. In fact, it's one of only a very few 3 hour films I watch repeatedly. In my opinion, David Soul was the movie's biggest asset.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Why, oh why, is this excellent film not available on DVD and Amazon Instant Video?  This film is an excellent rendition of the Ken Follett novel.  Cliff Robertson, David Soul, Robert Culp, and the supporting cast all turn in bravo performances in a thrilling story set in World War II Egypt.  Egypt is besieged by Rommel's powerful armies, and a master German spy (David Soul) is betraying vital British military secrets to Rommel to enable the final push to Cairo.  Cliff Robertson is the brilliant British counter-intelligence agent determined to stop him.  This is a gripping and well-told film, just like the book, which is one of Follet's best novels.  This film needs to be made available on DVD and Instant Video without further delay!  RJB.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Obviously, the book is almost always better, but for a movie rendition this did a pretty good job. I think that they brought the characters out very well. I would have liked to have seen some of the continuity of the book preserved, but I can understand why things were altered for the picture.I really would have liked to have this in DVD, but I could only find the VHS version.
summary: This was a good rendition of the book
Title: N/A
